Â 

FedPAQ: A Communication-Efficient Federated Learning Method with Periodic Averaging and Quantization


Â 


Amirhossein Reisizadeh Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Aryan Mokhtari Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Hamed Hassani UC Santa Barbara Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  UT Austin Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  UPenn

Ali Jadbabaie Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Ramtin Pedarsani MIT Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  UC Santa Barbara

Abstract

Federated learning is a distributed framework according to which a model is trained over a set of devices, while keeping data localized. This framework faces several systems-oriented challenges which include (i) communication bottleneck since a large number of devices upload their local updates to a parameter server, and (ii) scalability as the federated network consists of millions of devices. Due to these systems challenges as well as issues related to statistical heterogeneity of data and privacy concerns, designing a provably efficient federated learning method is of significant importance yet it remains challenging. In this paper, we present FedPAQ, a communication-efficient Federated Learning method with Periodic Averaging and Quantization. FedPAQ relies on three key features: (1) periodic averaging where models are updated locally at devices and only periodically averaged at the server; (2) partial device participation where only a fraction of devices participate in each round of the training; and (3) quantized message-passing where the edge nodes quantize their updates before uploading to the parameter server. These features address the communications and scalability challenges in federated learning. We also show that FedPAQ achieves near-optimal theoretical guarantees for strongly convex and non-convex loss functions and empirically demonstrate the communication-computation tradeoff provided by our method.

1 Introduction

In many large-scale machine learning applications, data is acquired and processed at the edge nodes of the network such as mobile devices, usersâ€™ devices, and IoT sensors. Federated Learning is a novel paradigm that aims to train a statistical model at the â€œedgeâ€ nodes as opposed to the traditional distributed computing systems such as data centers (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016; Li etÂ al., 2019a). The main objective of federated learning is to fit a model to data generated from network devices without continuous transfer of the massive amount of collected data from edge of the network to back-end servers for processing.

Federated learning has been deployed by major technology companies with the goal of providing privacy-preserving services using usersâ€™ data (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2019). Examples of such applications are learning from wearable devices (Huang etÂ al., 2018), learning sentiment (Smith etÂ al., 2017), and location-based services (Samarakoon etÂ al., 2018). While federated learning is a promising paradigm for such applications, there are several challenges that remain to be resolved. In this paper, we focus on two significant challenges of federated learning, and propose a novel federated learning algorithm that addresses the following two challenges:
(1) Communication bottleneck. Communication bandwidth is a major bottleneck in federated learning as a large number of devices attempt to communicate their local updates to a central parameter server. Thus, for a communication-efficient federated learning algorithm, it is crucial that such updates are sent in a compressed manner and infrequently.
(2) Scale. A federated network typically consists of thousands to millions of devices that may be active, slow, or completely inactive during the training procedure. Thus, a proposed federated learning algorithm should be able to operate efficiently with partial device participation or random sampling of devices.

The goal of this paper is to develop a provably efficient federated learning algorithm that addresses the above-mentioned systems challenges. More precisely, we consider the task of training a model in a federated learning setup where we aim to find an accurate model over a collection of nğ‘›n distributed nodes. In this setting, each node contains mğ‘šm independent and identically distributed samples from an unknown probability distribution and a parameter server helps coordination between the nodes. We focus on solving the empirical risk minimization problem for a federated architecture while addressing the challenges mentioned above. In particular, we consider both strongly convex and non-convex settings and provide sharp guarantees on the performance of our proposed algorithm.

Contributions. In this work, we propose FedPAQ, a communication-efficient Federated learning algorithm with Periodic Averaging and Quantization, which addresses federated learning systemsâ€™ bottlenecks. In particular, FedPAQ has three key features that enable efficient federated learning implementation:
(1) FedPAQ allows the nodes (users) of the network to run local training before synchronizing with the parameter server. In particular, each node iteratively updates its local model for a period of iterations using the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) method and then uploads its model to the parameter server where all the received models are averaged periodically. By tuning the parameter which corresponds to the number of local iterations before communicating to the server, periodic averaging results in slashing the number of communication rounds and hence the total communication cost of the training process.
(2) FedPAQ captures the constraint on availability of active edge nodes by allowing a partial node participation. That is, in each round of the method, only a fraction of the total devicesâ€“which are the active onesâ€“contribute to train the model. This procedure not only addresses the scalability challenge, but also leads to smaller communication load compared to the case that all nodes participate in training the learning model.
(3) In FedPAQ, nodes only send a quantized version of their local information to the server at each round of communication. As the training models are of large sizes, quantization significantly helps reducing the communication overhead on the network.

While these features have been proposed in the literature, to the best of our knowledge, FedPAQ is the first federated learning algorithm that simultaneously incorporates these features and provides near-optimal theoretical guarantees on its statistical accuracy, while being communication-efficient via periodic averaging, partial node participation and quantization.

In particular, we analyze our proposed FedPAQ method for two general class of loss functions: strongly-convex and non-convex. For the strongly-convex setting, we show that after Tğ‘‡T iterations the squared norm of the distance between the solution of our method and the optimal solution is of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡{\mathcal{O}}(1/T) in expectation. We also show that FedPAQ approaches a first-order stationary point for non-convex losses at a rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{T}). This demonstrates that our method significantly improves the communication-efficiency of federated learning while preserving the optimality and convergence guarantees of the baseline methods. In addition, we would like to highlight that our theoretical analysis is based on few relaxed and customary assumptions which yield more technical challenges compared to the existing works with stronger assumptions and hence acquires novel analytical techniques. More explanations will be provided in Section 4.

Related Work. The main premise of federated learning has been collective learning using a network of common devices such as phones and tablets. This framework potentially allows for smarter models, lower latency, and less power consumption, all while ensuring privacy. Successfully achieving these goals in practice requires addressing key challenges of federated learning such as communication complexity, systems heterogeneity, privacy, robustness, and heterogeneity of the users. Recently, many federated methods have been considered in the literature which mostly aim at reducing the communication cost. McMahan etÂ al. (2016) proposed the FedAvg algorithm, where the global model is updated by averaging local SGD updates. Guha etÂ al. (2019) proposed one-shot federated learning in which the master node learns the model after a single round of communication.

Optimization methods for federated learning are naturally tied with tools from stochastic and distributed optimization. Minibatch stochastic gradient descent distributed optimization methods have been largely studied in the literature without considering the communication bottleneck. Addressing the communication bottleneck via quantization and compression in distributed learning has recently gained considerable attention for both master-worker (Alistarh etÂ al., 2017; Seide etÂ al., 2014; Bernstein etÂ al., 2018; Smith etÂ al., 2016) and masterless topologies (Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2019a; Zhang etÂ al., 2018; Koloskova etÂ al., 2019; Wang etÂ al., 2019). Moreover, Wang etÂ al. (2019) reduces the communication delay by decomposing the graph.

Local updates, as another approach to reduce the communication load in distributed learning has been studied in the literature, where each learning node carries out multiple local updates before sharing with the master or its neighboring nodes. Stich (2018) considered a master-worker topology and provides theoretical analysis for the convergence of local-SGD method. Lin etÂ al. (2018) introduced a variant of local-SGD namely post-local-SGD which demonstrates empirical improvements over local-SGD. Wang and Joshi (2018) provided a general analysis of such cooperative method for decentralized settings as well.

Statistical heterogeneity of usersâ€™ data points is another major challenge in federated learning. To address this heterogeneity, other methods such as multitask learning and meta learning have been proposed to train multiple local models (Smith etÂ al., 2017; Nichol etÂ al., 2018; Li etÂ al., 2019b). Many methods have been proposed to address systems heterogeneity and in particular stragglers in distributed learning using coding theory, e.g., (Lee etÂ al., 2018; Yu etÂ al., 2017; Dutta etÂ al., 2016; Tandon etÂ al., 2016; Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2019b). Another important challenge in federated learning is to preserve privacy in learning (Duchi etÂ al., 2014). McMahan etÂ al. (2017); Agarwal etÂ al. (2018) proposed privacy-preserving methods for distributed and federated learning using differential privacy techniques. Federated heavy hitters discovery with differential privacy was proposed in (Zhu etÂ al., 2019).

Robustness against adversarial devices is another challenge in federated learning and distributed learning that has been studied in (Chen etÂ al., 2017; Yin etÂ al., 2018; Ghosh etÂ al., 2019). Finally, several works have considered communication-efficient collaborative learning where there is no master node, and the computing nodes learn a model collaboratively in a decentralized manner (Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2019a; Zhang etÂ al., 2018; Doan etÂ al., 2018; Koloskova etÂ al., 2019; Lalitha etÂ al., 2019). While such techniques are related to federated learning, the network topology in master-less collaborative learning is fundamentally different.

2 Federated Learning Setup

In this paper, we focus on a federated architecture where a parameter server (or server) aims at finding a model that performs well with respect to the data points that are available at different nodes (users) of the network, while nodes exchange their local information with the server. We further assume that the data points for all nodes in the network are generated from a common probability distribution. In particular, we consider the following stochastic learning problem

minğ±â¡fâ€‹(ğ±)â‰”minğ±â¡1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nfiâ€‹(ğ±),â‰”subscriptğ±ğ‘“ğ±subscriptğ±1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±\min_{{\mathbf{x}}}f({\mathbf{x}})\coloneqq\min_{{\mathbf{x}}}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}),\vspace{-1mm} (1)

where the local objective function of each node iğ‘–i is defined as the expected loss of its local sample distributions

fiâ€‹(ğ±)â‰”ğ”¼Î¾âˆ¼ğ’«iâ€‹[â„“â€‹(ğ±,Î¾)].â‰”subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±subscriptğ”¼similar-toğœ‰superscriptğ’«ğ‘–delimited-[]â„“ğ±ğœ‰f_{i}({\mathbf{x}})\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\xi\sim{\mathcal{P}}^{i}}\,[\ell(\mathbf{x},\xi)].\vspace{-1mm} (2)

Here â„“:â„pÃ—â„uâ†’â„:â„“superscriptâ„ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘¢â†’â„\ell\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathbb{R}^{p}\times\mathbb{R}^{u}\to\mathbb{R} is a stochastic loss function, ğ±âˆˆâ„pğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{p} is the model vector, and Î¾âˆˆâ„uğœ‰superscriptâ„ğ‘¢\xi\in\mathbb{R}^{u} is a random variable with unknown probability distribution ğ’«isuperscriptğ’«ğ‘–{\mathcal{P}}^{i}. Moreover, f:â„pâ†’â„:ğ‘“superscriptâ„ğ‘â†’â„f\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathbb{R}^{p}\to\mathbb{R} denotes the expected loss function also called population risk. In our considered federated setting, each of the nğ‘›n distributed nodes generates a local loss function according to a distribution ğ’«isuperscriptğ’«ğ‘–{\mathcal{P}}^{i} resulting in a local stochastic function fiâ€‹(ğ±)â‰”ğ”¼Î¾âˆ¼ğ’«iâ€‹[â„“â€‹(ğ±,Î¾)]â‰”subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±subscriptğ”¼similar-toğœ‰superscriptğ’«ğ‘–delimited-[]â„“ğ±ğœ‰f_{i}({\mathbf{x}})\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\xi\sim{\mathcal{P}}^{i}}\,[\ell(\mathbf{x},\xi)]. A special case of this formulation is when each node iğ‘–i maintains a collection of mğ‘šm samples from distribution ğ’«isuperscriptğ’«ğ‘–{\mathcal{P}}^{i} which we denote by ğ’Ÿi={Î¾1i,â‹¯,Î¾mi}superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğœ‰ğ‘–1â‹¯subscriptsuperscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ‘š{\mathcal{D}}^{i}=\{\xi^{i}_{1},\cdots,\xi^{i}_{m}\} for iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]. This results in the following empirical risk minimization problem over the collection of nâ€‹mğ‘›ğ‘šnm samples in ğ’Ÿâ‰”ğ’Ÿ1âˆªâ‹¯âˆªğ’Ÿnâ‰”ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿ1â‹¯superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›{\mathcal{D}}\coloneqq{\mathcal{D}}^{1}\cup\cdots\cup{\mathcal{D}}^{n}:

minğ±â¡Lâ€‹(ğ±)=minğ±â¡1nâ€‹mâ€‹âˆ‘Î¾âˆˆğ’Ÿâ„“â€‹(ğ±,Î¾),subscriptğ±ğ¿ğ±subscriptğ±1ğ‘›ğ‘šsubscriptğœ‰ğ’Ÿâ„“ğ±ğœ‰\min_{{\mathbf{x}}}L({\mathbf{x}})=\min_{{\mathbf{x}}}\frac{1}{nm}\sum_{\xi\in{\mathcal{D}}}\ell({\mathbf{x}},\xi),\vspace{-1mm} (3)

We denote the optimal model ğ±âˆ—superscriptğ±{\mathbf{x}}^{*} as the solution to the expected risk minimization problem in (1) and denote the minimum loss fâˆ—â‰”minğ±â¡fâ€‹(ğ±)=fâ€‹(ğ±âˆ—)â‰”superscriptğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘“ğ±ğ‘“superscriptğ±f^{*}\coloneqq\min_{{\mathbf{x}}}f({\mathbf{x}})=f({\mathbf{x}}^{*}) as the optimal objective function value of the expected risk minimization problem in (1). In this work, we focus on the case that the data over the nğ‘›n nodes is independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.), which implies the local distributions are common.

As stated above, our goal is to minimize the expected loss fâ€‹(ğ±)ğ‘“ğ±f(\mathbf{x}). However, due to the fact that we do not have access to the underlying distribution ğ’«ğ’«{\mathcal{P}}, there have been prior works that focus on minimizing the empirical risk Lâ€‹(ğ±)ğ¿ğ±L(\mathbf{x}) which can be viewed as an approximation of the expected loss fâ€‹(ğ±)ğ‘“ğ±f(\mathbf{x}). The accuracy of this approximation is determined by the number of samples N=nâ€‹mğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘šN=nm. It has been shown that for convex losses â„“â„“\ell, the population risk fğ‘“f is at most ğ’ªâ€‹(1/nâ€‹m)ğ’ª1ğ‘›ğ‘š{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}) distant from the empirical risk Lğ¿L, uniformly and with high probability (Bottou and Bousquet, 2008). That is, supğ±|fâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’Lâ€‹(ğ±)|â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(1/nâ€‹m)subscriptsupremumğ±ğ‘“ğ±ğ¿ğ±ğ’ª1ğ‘›ğ‘š\sup_{\mathbf{x}}|f(\mathbf{x})-L(\mathbf{x})|\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}) with high probability. This result implies that if each of the nğ‘›n nodes separately minimizes its local empirical loss function, the expected deviation from the local solution and the solution to the population risk minimization problem is of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/m)ğ’ª1ğ‘š{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{m}) (note that each node has access to mğ‘šm data samples). However, if the nodes manage to somehow share or synchronize their solutions, then a more accurate solution can be achieved, that is a solution with accuracy of order ğ’ªâ€‹(1/nâ€‹m)ğ’ª1ğ‘›ğ‘š{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}). Therefore, when all the mâ€‹nğ‘šğ‘›mn available samples are leveraged, one can obtain a solution ğ±^^ğ±\hat{\mathbf{x}} that satisfies ğ”¼â€‹[Lâ€‹(ğ±^)âˆ’Lâ€‹(ğ±âˆ—)]â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(1/nâ€‹m)ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¿^ğ±ğ¿superscriptğ±ğ’ª1ğ‘›ğ‘š\mathbb{E}[L(\hat{\mathbf{x}})-L(\mathbf{x}^{*})]\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}). This also implies that ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ±^)âˆ’minğ±â¡fâ€‹(ğ±)]â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(1/nâ€‹m)ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“^ğ±subscriptğ±ğ‘“ğ±ğ’ª1ğ‘›ğ‘š\mathbb{E}[f(\hat{\mathbf{x}})-\min_{\mathbf{x}}f(\mathbf{x})]\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}).

For the case of non-convex loss function â„“â„“\ell, however, finding the solution to the expected risk minimization problem in (1) is hard. Even further, finding (or testing) a local optimum is NP-hard in many cases (Murty and Kabadi, 1987). Therefore, for non-convex losses we relax our main goal and instead look for first-order optimal solutions (or stationary points) for (1). That is, we aim to find a model ğ±^^ğ±\hat{\mathbf{x}} that satisfies âˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±^)âˆ¥â‰¤Ïµdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“^ğ±italic-Ïµ\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f(\hat{\mathbf{x}})\right\rVert}\leq\epsilon for an arbitrarily small approximation error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Mei etÂ al. (2018) characterized the gap for the gradients of the two expected risk and empirical risk functions. That is, if the gradient of loss is sub-Gaussian, then with high probability supğ±âˆ¥âˆ‡Lâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ¥â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(1/nâ€‹m)subscriptsupremumğ±delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¿ğ±âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±ğ’ª1ğ‘›ğ‘š\sup_{\mathbf{x}}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla L(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right\rVert}\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}). This result further implies that having all the nodes contribute in minimizing the empirical risk results in better approximation for a first-order stationary point of the expected risk Lğ¿L. In summary, our goal in non-convex setting is to find ğ±^^ğ±\hat{\mathbf{x}} that satisfies âˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ¥â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(1/nâ€‹m)delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±ğ’ª1ğ‘›ğ‘š\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right\rVert}\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}) which also implies âˆ¥âˆ‡Lâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ¥â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(1/nâ€‹m)delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ¿ğ±ğ’ª1ğ‘›ğ‘š\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla L(\mathbf{x})\right\rVert}\leq{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{nm}).

3 Proposed FedPAQ Method

In this section, we present our proposed communication-efficient federated learning method called FedPAQ, which consists of three main modules: (1) periodic averaging, (2) partial node participation, and (3) quantized message passing.

3.1 Periodic averaging

As explained in Section 2, to leverage from all the available data samples on the nodes, any training method should incorporate synchronizing the intermediate models obtained at local devices. One approach is to let the participating nodes synchronize their models through the parameter server in each iteration of the training. This, however, implies many rounds of communication between the federated nodes and the parameter server which results in communication contention over the network. Instead, we let the participating nodes conduct a number of local updates and synchronize through the parameter server periodically. To be more specific, once nodes pull an updated model from the server, they update the model locally by running Ï„ğœ\tau iterations of the SGD method and then send proper information to the server for updating the aggregate model. Indeed, this periodic averaging scheme reduces the rounds of communication between server and the nodes and consequently the overall communication cost of training the model. In particular, for the case that we plan to run Tğ‘‡T iterations of SGD at each node, nodes need to communicate with the server K=T/Ï„ğ¾ğ‘‡ğœK=T/\tau rounds, hence reducing the total communication cost by a factor of 1/Ï„1ğœ1/\tau.

Choosing a larger value of Ï„ğœ\tau indeed reduces the rounds of communication for a fixed number of iterations Tğ‘‡T. However, if our goal is to obtain a specific accuracy Îµğœ€\varepsilon, choosing a very large value for Ï„ğœ\tau is not necessarily optimal as by increasing Ï„ğœ\tau the noise of the system increases and the local models approach the local optimal solutions instead of the global optimal solution. Hence, we might end up running more iterations Tğ‘‡T to achieve a specific accuracy Îµğœ€\varepsilon comparing to a case that Ï„ğœ\tau is small. Indeed, a crucial question that we need to address is finding the optimal choice of Ï„ğœ\tau for minimizing the overall communication cost of the process.

3.2 Partial node participation

In a federated network, often there is a large number of devices such as smart phones communicating through a base station. On one hand, base stations have limited download bandwidth and hence only a few of devices are able to simultaneously upload their messages to the base station. Due to this limitation the messages sent from the devices will be pipelined at the base station which results in a dramatically slow training. On the other hand, having all of the devices participate through the whole training process induces a large communication overhead on the network which is often costly. Moreover, in practice not all the devices contribute in each round of the training. Indeed, there are multiple factors that determine whether a device can participate in the training (McMahan and Ramage, 2017): a device should be available in the reachable range of the base station; a device should be idle, plugged in and connected to a free wireless network during the training; etc.

Our proposed FedPAQ method captures the restrictions mentioned above. In particular, we assume that among the total of nğ‘›n devices, only rğ‘Ÿr nodes (râ‰¤nğ‘Ÿğ‘›r\leq n) are available in each round of the training. We can also assume that due to the availability criterion described before, such available devices are randomly and uniformly distributed over the network (Sahu etÂ al., 2018). In summary, in each period k=0,1,â‹¯,Kâˆ’1ğ‘˜01â‹¯ğ¾1k=0,1,\cdots,K-1 of the training algorithm, the parameter server sends its current model ğ±ksubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}_{k} to all the rğ‘Ÿr nodes in subset ğ’®ksubscriptğ’®ğ‘˜{\mathcal{S}}_{k}, which are distributed uniformly at random among the total nğ‘›n nodes, i.e., Prâ€‹[ğ’®k]=1/(nr)Prdelimited-[]subscriptğ’®ğ‘˜1binomialğ‘›ğ‘Ÿ\text{Pr}\left[{\mathcal{S}}_{k}\right]=1/{n\choose r}.

3.3 Quantized message-passing

Another aspect of the communication bottleneck in federated learning is the limited uplink bandwidth at the devices which makes the communication from devices to the parameter server slow and expensive. Hence, it is critical to reduce the size of the uploaded messages from the federated devices (Li etÂ al., 2019a). Our proposal is to employ quantization operators on the transmitted massages. Depending on the accuracy of the quantizer, the network communication overhead is reduced by exchanging the quantized updates.

In the proposed FedPAQ, each node iâˆˆğ’®kğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘˜i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{k} obtains the model ğ±k,Ï„(i)subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœ\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau} after running Ï„ğœ\tau local iterations of an optimization method (possibly SGD) on the most recent model ğ±ksubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}_{k} that it has received form the server. Then each node iğ‘–i applies a quantizer operator Qâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘„â‹…Q(\cdot) on the difference between the received model and its updated model, i.e., ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±ksubscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}, and uploads the quantized vector Qâ€‹(ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±k)ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜Q(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}) to the parameter server. Once these quantized vectors are sent to the server, it decodes the quantized signals and combines them to come up with a new model ğ±k+1subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}.

Next, we describe a widely-used random quantizer.

Example 1 (Low-precision quantizer (Alistarh etÂ al., 2017)).

For any variable ğ±âˆˆâ„pğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{p}, the low precision quantizer QLP:â„pâ†’â„p:superscriptğ‘„LPsuperscriptâ„ğ‘â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘Q^{\text{LP}}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\mathbb{R}^{p}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p} is defined as below

QiLPâ€‹(ğ±)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„LPğ‘–ğ±\displaystyle Q^{\text{LP}}_{i}(\mathbf{x}) =âˆ¥ğ±âˆ¥â‹…signâ€‹(xi)â‹…Î¾iâ€‹(ğ±,s),iâˆˆ[p],formulae-sequenceabsentâ‹…â‹…delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±signsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ±ğ‘ ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘\displaystyle=\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}\right\rVert}\cdot{\rm{sign}}(x_{i})\cdot\xi_{i}(\mathbf{x},s),\quad i\in[p], (4)

where Î¾iâ€‹(ğ±,s)subscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ±ğ‘ \xi_{i}(\mathbf{x},s) is a random variable taking on value l+1/sğ‘™1ğ‘ \nicefrac{{l+1}}{{s}} with probability |xi|âˆ¥ğ±âˆ¥â€‹sâˆ’lsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±ğ‘ ğ‘™\frac{|x_{i}|}{\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}\right\rVert}}s-l and l/sğ‘™ğ‘ \nicefrac{{l}}{{s}} otherwise. Here, the tuning parameter sğ‘ s corresponds to the number of quantization levels and lâˆˆ[0,s)ğ‘™0ğ‘ l\in[0,s) is an integer such that |xi|/âˆ¥ğ±âˆ¥âˆˆ[l/s,l+1/s)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘™1ğ‘ \nicefrac{{|x_{i}|}}{{\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}\right\rVert}}}\in[\nicefrac{{l}}{{s}},\nicefrac{{l+1}}{{s}}).

3.4 Algorithm update

Now we use the building blocks developed in Sections 3.1-3.3 to precisely present FedPAQ. Our proposed method consists of Kğ¾K periods, and during a period, each node performs Ï„ğœ\tau local updates, which results in total number of T=Kâ€‹Ï„ğ‘‡ğ¾ğœT=K\tau iterations. In each period k=0,â‹¯,Kâˆ’1ğ‘˜0â‹¯ğ¾1k=0,\cdots,K-1 of the algorithm, the parameter server picks râ‰¤nğ‘Ÿğ‘›r\leq n nodes uniformly at random which we denote by ğ’®ksubscriptğ’®ğ‘˜{\mathcal{S}}_{k}. The parameter server then broadcasts its current model ğ±ksubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}_{k} to all the nodes in ğ’®ksubscriptğ’®ğ‘˜{\mathcal{S}}_{k} and each node iâˆˆğ’®kğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘˜i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{k} performs Ï„ğœ\tau local SGD updates using its local dataset. To be more specific, let ğ±k,t(i)subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t} denote the model at node iğ‘–i at tğ‘¡t-th iteration of the kğ‘˜k-th period. At each local iteration t=0,â‹¯,Ï„âˆ’1ğ‘¡0â‹¯ğœ1t=0,\cdots,\tau-1, node iğ‘–i updates its local model according to the following rule:

ğ±k,t+1(i)=ğ±k,t(i)âˆ’Î·k,tâ€‹âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±k,t(i)),subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğ‘¡~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t+1}=\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t}-\eta_{k,t}\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t}\right),\vspace{-1mm} (5)

where the stochastic gradient âˆ‡~â€‹fi~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i} is computed using a random sample111The method can be easily made compatible with using a mini-batch during each iteration. picked from the local dataset ğ’Ÿisuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\mathcal{D}}^{i}. Note that all the nodes begin with a common initialization ğ±k,0(i)=ğ±ksubscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜0subscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,0}=\mathbf{x}_{k}. After Ï„ğœ\tau local updates, each node computes the overall update in that period, that is ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±ksubscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}, and uploads a quantized update Qâ€‹(ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±k)ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜Q(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}) to the parameter server.

The parameter server then aggregates the rğ‘Ÿr received quantized local updates and computes the next model according to

ğ±k+1=ğ±k+1râ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®kQâ€‹(ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±k),subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘˜ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}_{k+1}=\mathbf{x}_{k}+\frac{1}{r}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{k}}Q\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right),\vspace{-1mm} (6)

and the procedure is repeated for Kğ¾K periods. The proposed method is formally summarized in AlgorithmÂ 1.

4 Convergence Analysis

In this section, we present our theoretical results on the guarantees of the FedPAQ method. We first consider the strongly convex setting and state the convergence guarantee of FedPAQ for such losses in TheoremÂ 1. Then, in TheoremÂ 2, we present the overall complexity of our method for finding a first-order stationary point of the aggregate objective function fğ‘“f, when the loss function â„“â„“\ell is non-convex (All proofs are provided in the supplementary material). Before that, we first mention three customary assumptions required for both convex and non-convex settings.

Assumption 1.

The random quantizer Qâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘„â‹…Q(\cdot) is unbiased and its variance grows with the squared of l2subscriptğ‘™2l_{2}-norm of its argument, i.e.,

ğ”¼â€‹[Qâ€‹(ğ±)|ğ±]=ğ±,ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ¥Qâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’ğ±âˆ¥2|ğ±]â‰¤qâ€‹âˆ¥ğ±âˆ¥2,formulae-sequenceğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalğ‘„ğ±ğ±ğ±ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘„ğ±ğ±2ğ±ğ‘superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±2\mathbb{E}\left[Q(\mathbf{x})|\mathbf{x}\right]=\mathbf{x},\quad\mathbb{E}\left[\mathinner{\!\left\lVert Q(\mathbf{x})-\mathbf{x}\right\rVert}^{2}|\mathbf{x}\right]\leq q\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}\right\rVert}^{2},\vspace{-1mm} (7)

for some positive real constant qğ‘q and any ğ±âˆˆâ„pğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘\mathbf{x}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{p}.

Assumption 2.

The loss functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} are Lğ¿L-smooth with respect to ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}, i.e., for any ğ±,ğ±^âˆˆâ„pğ±^ğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘\mathbf{x},{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{p}, we have âˆ¥âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±^)âˆ¥â‰¤Lâ€‹âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ±^âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–^ğ±ğ¿delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±^ğ±\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f_{i}({\hat{\mathbf{x}}})\right\rVert}\leq L\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\right\rVert}.

Assumption 3.

Stochastic gradients âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±)~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x}) are unbiased and variance bounded, i.e., ğ”¼Î¾â€‹[âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±)]=âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±)subscriptğ”¼ğœ‰delimited-[]~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x})]=\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x}) and ğ”¼Î¾â€‹[â€–âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2]â‰¤Ïƒ2.subscriptğ”¼ğœ‰delimited-[]superscriptnorm~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±2superscriptğœ2\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[\|\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}.

The conditions in AssumptionÂ 1 ensure that output of quantization is an unbiased estimator of the input with a variance that is proportional to the norm-squared of the input. This condition is satisfied with most common quantization schemes including the low-precision quantizer introduced in ExampleÂ 1. Assumption 2 implies that the gradients of local functions âˆ‡fiâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\nabla f_{i} and the aggregated objective function âˆ‡fâˆ‡ğ‘“\nabla f are also Lğ¿L-Lipschitz continuous. The conditions in Assumption 3 on the bias and variance of stochastic gradients are also customary. Note that this is a much weaker assumption compared to the one that uniformly bounds the expected norm of the stochastic gradient.

Challenges in analyzing the FedPAQ method. Here, we highlight the main theoretical challenges in proving our main results. As outlined in the description of the proposed method, in the kğ‘˜k-th round of FedPAQ, each participating node iğ‘–i updates its local model for Ï„ğœ\tau iterations via SGD method inÂ (5). Let us focus on a case that we use a constant stepsize for the purpose of this discussion. First consider the naive parallel SGD case which corresponds to Ï„=1ğœ1\tau=1. The updated local model after Ï„=1ğœ1\tau=1 local update is

ğ±k,Ï„(i)=ğ±k,0(i)âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±k,0(i)).subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜0ğœ‚~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜0\displaystyle\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}=\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,0}-\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,0}\right). (8)

Note that ğ±k,0(i)=ğ±ksubscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜0subscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,0}=\mathbf{x}_{k} is the parameter serverâ€™s model sent to the nodes. Since we assume the stochastic gradients are unbiased estimators of the gradient, it yields that the local update ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±ksubscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k} is an unbiased estimator of âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±k)ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘˜-\eta\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{k}) for every participating node. Hence, the aggregated updates at the server and the updated model ğ±k+1subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1\mathbf{x}_{k+1} can be simply related to the current model ğ±ksubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}_{k} as one step of parallel SGD. However, this is not the case when the period length Ï„ğœ\tau is larger than 111. For instance, in the case that Ï„=2ğœ2\tau=2, the local updated model after Ï„=2ğœ2\tau=2 iterations is

ğ±k,Ï„(i)=ğ±kâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±k)âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±kâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±k)).subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğœ‚~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğœ‚~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğœ‚~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘˜\displaystyle\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}\!=\!\mathbf{x}_{k}\!-\!\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\right)\!-\!\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\!-\!\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}_{k}\right)\right). (9)

Clearly, ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±ksubscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k} is not an unbiased estimator of âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±k)ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘˜-\eta\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{k}) or âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±kâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±k))ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘˜-\eta\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{k})). This demonstrates that the aggregated model at server cannot be treated as Ï„ğœ\tau iterations of parallel SGD, since each local update contains a bias. Indeed, this bias gets propagated when Ï„ğœ\tau gets larger. For our running example Ï„=2ğœ2\tau=2, the variance of the bias, i.e. ğ”¼â€‹â€–Î·â€‹âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±kâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±k))â€–2ğ”¼superscriptnormğœ‚~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘˜ğœ‚~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘˜2\mathbb{E}\|\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{k}))\|^{2} is not uniformly bounded either (Assumption 3), which makes the analysis even more challenging compared to the works with bounded gradient assumption (e.g. (Stich, 2018; Yu etÂ al., 2019)).

4.1 Strongly convex setting

Now we proceed to establish the convergence rate of the proposed FedPAQ method for a federated setting with strongly convex and smooth loss function â„“â„“\ell. We first formally state the strong convexity assumption.

Assumption 4.

The loss functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} are Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex, i.e., for any ğ±,ğ±^âˆˆâ„pğ±^ğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘\mathbf{x},{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{p} we have that âŸ¨âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±^),ğ±âˆ’ğ±^âŸ©â‰¥Î¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ±^âˆ¥2.âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–^ğ±ğ±^ğ±ğœ‡superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±^ğ±2\langle\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f_{i}({\hat{\mathbf{x}}}),\mathbf{x}-{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\rangle\geq\mu\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-{\hat{\mathbf{x}}}\right\rVert}^{2}.

Theorem 1 (Strongly convex loss).

Consider the sequence of iterates ğ±ksubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}_{k} at the parameter server generated according to the FedPAQ method outlined in AlgorithmÂ 1. Suppose the conditions in Assumptions 1â€“4 are satisfied. Further, let us define the constant B1subscriptğµ1B_{1} as

B1=2â€‹L2â€‹(qn+nâˆ’rrâ€‹(nâˆ’1)â€‹4â€‹(1+q)),subscriptğµ12superscriptğ¿2ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›141ğ‘B_{1}=2L^{2}\left(\frac{q}{n}+\frac{n-r}{r(n-1)}4(1+q)\right),\vspace{-1mm} (10)

where qğ‘q is the quantization variance parameter defined in (7) and rğ‘Ÿr is the number of active nodes at each round of communication. If we set the stepsize in FedPAQ as Î·k,t=Î·k=4â€‹Î¼âˆ’1/kâ€‹Ï„+1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜4superscriptğœ‡1ğ‘˜ğœ1\eta_{k,t}=\eta_{k}=\nicefrac{{4\mu^{-1}}}{{k\tau+1}}, then for any kâ‰¥k0ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘˜0k\geq k_{0} where k0subscriptğ‘˜0k_{0} is the smallest integer satisfying

k0â‰¥4â€‹maxâ¡{LÎ¼,4â€‹(B1Î¼2+1),1Ï„,4â€‹nÎ¼2â€‹Ï„},subscriptğ‘˜04ğ¿ğœ‡4subscriptğµ1superscriptğœ‡211ğœ4ğ‘›superscriptğœ‡2ğœk_{0}\geq 4\max\bigg{\{}\frac{L}{\mu},4\left(\frac{B_{1}}{\mu^{2}}+1\right),\frac{1}{\tau},\frac{4n}{\mu^{2}\tau}\bigg{\}},\vspace{-1mm} (11)

the expected error ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ±kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—â€–]2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-[]normsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜superscriptğ±2\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{x}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\|]^{2} is bounded above by

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2â‰¤(k0â€‹Ï„+1)2(kâ€‹Ï„+1)2â€‹âˆ¥ğ±k0âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜superscriptğ±2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğœ12superscriptğ‘˜ğœ12superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±subscriptğ‘˜0superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}\leq\frac{(k_{0}\tau+1)^{2}}{(k\tau+1)^{2}}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k_{0}}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} (12)
+C1â€‹Ï„kâ€‹Ï„+1+C2â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)2kâ€‹Ï„+1+C3â€‹Ï„âˆ’1(kâ€‹Ï„+1)2,subscriptğ¶1ğœğ‘˜ğœ1subscriptğ¶2superscriptğœ12ğ‘˜ğœ1subscriptğ¶3ğœ1superscriptğ‘˜ğœ12\displaystyle\quad+C_{1}\frac{\tau}{k\tau+1}+C_{2}\frac{(\tau-1)^{2}}{k\tau+1}+C_{3}\frac{\tau-1}{(k\tau+1)^{2}}, (13)

where the constants in (13) are defined as

C1subscriptğ¶1\displaystyle\!\!C_{1}\! =16â€‹Ïƒ2Î¼2â€‹nâ€‹(1+2â€‹q+8â€‹(1+q)â€‹nâ€‹(nâˆ’r)râ€‹(nâˆ’1)),C2=16â€‹eâ€‹L2â€‹Ïƒ2Î¼2â€‹n,formulae-sequenceabsent16superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ‡2ğ‘›12ğ‘81ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›1subscriptğ¶216ğ‘’superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ‡2ğ‘›\displaystyle=\!\frac{16\sigma^{2}}{\mu^{2}n}\!\left(\!1\!+\!2q+\!8(1\!+\!q)\frac{n(n\!-\!r)}{r(n\!-\!1)}\!\right)\!,\ C_{2}\!=\!\frac{16eL^{2}\sigma^{2}}{\mu^{2}n}, (14)
C3subscriptğ¶3\displaystyle\!C_{3}\! =256â€‹eâ€‹L2â€‹Ïƒ2Î¼4â€‹nâ€‹(n+2â€‹q+8â€‹(1+q)â€‹nâ€‹(nâˆ’r)râ€‹(nâˆ’1)).absent256ğ‘’superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ‡4ğ‘›ğ‘›2ğ‘81ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›1\displaystyle=\frac{256eL^{2}\sigma^{2}}{\mu^{4}n}\left(n+2q+8(1+q)\frac{n(n-r)}{r(n-1)}\right). (15)
Remark 1.

Under the same conditions as in TheoremÂ 1 and for a total number of iterations T=Kâ€‹Ï„â‰¥k0â€‹Ï„ğ‘‡ğ¾ğœsubscriptğ‘˜0ğœT=K\tau\geq k_{0}\tau we have the following convergence rate

ğ”¼â€‹â€–ğ±Kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—â€–2â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„T)+ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„2T2)ğ”¼superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ¾superscriptğ±2ğ’ªğœğ‘‡ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘‡2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{x}_{K}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\|^{2}\leq{\mathcal{O}}\bigg{(}\frac{\tau}{T}\bigg{)}+{\mathcal{O}}\bigg{(}\frac{\tau^{2}}{T^{2}}\bigg{)} (16)
+ğ’ªâ€‹((Ï„âˆ’1)2T)+ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„âˆ’1T2).ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ12ğ‘‡ğ’ªğœ1superscriptğ‘‡2\displaystyle\quad+{\mathcal{O}}\bigg{(}\frac{(\tau-1)^{2}}{T}\bigg{)}+{\mathcal{O}}\bigg{(}\frac{\tau-1}{T^{2}}\bigg{)}. (17)

As expected, the fastest convergence rate is attained when the contributing nodes synchronize with the parameter server in each iteration, i.e. when Ï„=1ğœ1\tau=1. Theorem 1 however characterizes how large the period length Ï„ğœ\tau can be picked. In particular, any pick of Ï„=oâ€‹(T)ğœğ‘œğ‘‡\tau=o(\sqrt{T}) ensures the convergence of the FedPAQ to the global optimal for strongly convex losses.

Remark 2.

By setting Ï„=1ğœ1\tau=1, q=0ğ‘0q=0 and r=nğ‘Ÿğ‘›r=n, Theorem 1 recovers the convergence rate of vanilla parallel SGD, i.e., ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡{\mathcal{O}}(1/T) for strongly-convex losses. Our result is however more general since we remove the uniformly bounded assumption on the norm of stochastic gradient. For Ï„â‰¥1ğœ1\tau\geq 1, Theorem 1 does not recover the result in (Stich, 2018) due to our weaker condition in Assumption 3. Nevertheless, the same rate ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡{\mathcal{O}}(1/T) is guaranteed by FedPAQ for constant values of Ï„ğœ\tau.

4.2 Non-convex setting

We now present the convergence result of FedPAQ for smooth non-convex loss functions.

Theorem 2 (Non-convex Losses).

Consider the sequence of iterates ğ±ksubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}_{k} at the parameter server generated according to the FedPAQ method outlined in AlgorithmÂ 1. Suppose the conditions in Assumptions 1â€“3 are satisfied. Further, let us define the constant B2subscriptğµ2B_{2} as

B2â‰”qn+4â€‹(nâˆ’r)râ€‹(nâˆ’1)â€‹(1+q),â‰”subscriptğµ2ğ‘ğ‘›4ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›11ğ‘B_{2}\coloneqq\frac{q}{n}+\frac{4(n-r)}{r(n-1)}(1+q),\vspace{-1mm} (18)

where qğ‘q is the quantization variance parameter defined in (7) and rğ‘Ÿr is the number of active nodes at each round. If the total number of iterations Tğ‘‡T and the period length Ï„ğœ\tau satisfy the following conditions,

Tâ‰¥2,Ï„â‰¤B22+0.8âˆ’B28â€‹T,formulae-sequenceğ‘‡2ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğµ220.8subscriptğµ28ğ‘‡T\geq 2,\qquad\tau\leq\frac{\sqrt{B_{2}^{2}+0.8}-B_{2}}{8}\sqrt{T},\vspace{-1mm} (19)

and we set the stepsize as Î·k,t=1/Lâ€‹Tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğ‘¡1ğ¿ğ‘‡\eta_{k,t}=\nicefrac{{1}}{{L\sqrt{T}}}, then the following first-order stationary condition holds

1Tâ€‹âˆ‘k=0Kâˆ’1âˆ‘t=0Ï„âˆ’1ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±Â¯k,t)âˆ¥21ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğœ1ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f(\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,t})\right\rVert}^{2} (20)
â‰¤2â€‹Lâ€‹(fâ€‹(ğ±0)âˆ’fâˆ—)T+N1â€‹1T+N2â€‹Ï„âˆ’1T,absent2ğ¿ğ‘“subscriptğ±0superscriptğ‘“ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘11ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘2ğœ1ğ‘‡\displaystyle\quad\leq\frac{2L(f(\mathbf{x}_{0})-f^{*})}{\sqrt{T}}+N_{1}\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}+N_{2}\frac{\tau-1}{T}, (21)

where the constants in (21) are defined as

N1â‰”(1+q)â€‹Ïƒ2nâ€‹(1+nâ€‹(nâˆ’r)râ€‹(nâˆ’1)),N2â‰”Ïƒ2nâ€‹(n+1).formulae-sequenceâ‰”subscriptğ‘11ğ‘superscriptğœ2ğ‘›1ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›1â‰”subscriptğ‘2superscriptğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘›1\displaystyle N_{1}\coloneqq(1+q)\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}\left(1+\frac{n(n-r)}{r(n-1)}\right),\quad\!\!N_{2}\coloneqq\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}(n+1).
Remark 3.

The result in Theorem 2 implies the following order-wise rate

1Tâ€‹âˆ‘k=0Kâˆ’1âˆ‘t=0Ï„âˆ’1ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±Â¯k,t)âˆ¥2â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(1T)+ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„âˆ’1T).1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğœ1ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡2ğ’ª1ğ‘‡ğ’ªğœ1ğ‘‡\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\sum_{t=0}^{\tau-1}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f(\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,t})\right\rVert}^{2}\leq{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right)+{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{\tau\!-\!1}{T}\right).

Clearly, the fastest convergence rate is achieved for the smallest possible period length, i.e., Ï„=1ğœ1\tau=1. This however implies that the edge nodes communicate with the parameter server in each iteration, i.e. Tğ‘‡T rounds of communications which is costly. On the other hand, the conditions (19) in Theorem 2 allow the period length Ï„ğœ\tau to grow up to ğ’ªâ€‹(T)ğ’ªğ‘‡{\mathcal{O}}(\sqrt{T}) which results in an overall convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{T}) in reaching an stationary point. This result shows that with only ğ’ªâ€‹(T)ğ’ªğ‘‡{\mathcal{O}}(\sqrt{T}) rounds of communication FedPAQ can still ensure the convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{T}) for non-convex losses.

Remark 4.

Theorem 2 recovers the convergence rate of the vanilla parallel SGD (Yu etÂ al., 2019) for non-convex losses as a special case of Ï„=1ğœ1\tau=1, q=0ğ‘0q=0 and r=nğ‘Ÿğ‘›r=n. Nevertheless, we remove the uniformly bounded assumption on the norm of the stochastic gradient in our theoretical analysis. We also recover the result in (Wang and Joshi, 2018) when there is no quatization q=0ğ‘0q=0 and we have a full device participation r=nğ‘Ÿğ‘›r=n.

It is worth mentioning that for Theorems 1 and 2, one can use a batch of size mğ‘šm for each local SGD update and the same results hold by changing Ïƒ2/nsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘›\nicefrac{{\sigma^{2}}}{{n}} to Ïƒ2/mâ€‹nsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘šğ‘›\nicefrac{{\sigma^{2}}}{{mn}}.

5 Numerical Results and Discussions

The proposed FedPAQ method reduces the communication load by employing three modules: periodic averaging, partial node participation, and quantization. This communication reduction however comes with a cost in reducing the convergence accuracy and hence requiring more iterations of the training, which we characterized in Theorems 1 and 2. In this section, we empirically study this communication-computation trade-off and evaluate FedPAQ in comparison to other benchmarks. To evaluate the total cost of a method, we first need to specifically model such cost. We consider the total training time as the cost objective which consists of communication and computation time (Berahas etÂ al., 2018; Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2019c). Consider Tğ‘‡T iterations of training with FedPAQ that consists of K=T/Ï„ğ¾ğ‘‡ğœK=T/\tau rounds of communication. In each round, rğ‘Ÿr workers compute Ï„ğœ\tau iterations of SGD with batchsize BğµB and send a quantized vector of size pğ‘p to the server.

Communication time. We fix a bandwidth BW and define the communication time in each round as the total number of uploaded bits divided by BW. Total number of bits in each round is râ‹…|Qâ€‹(p,s)|â‹…ğ‘Ÿğ‘„ğ‘ğ‘ r\cdot|Q(p,s)|, where |Qâ€‹(p,s)|ğ‘„ğ‘ğ‘ |Q(p,s)| denotes the number of bits required to encode a quantized vector of dimension pğ‘p according to a specific quantizer with sğ‘ s levels. In our simulations, we use the low-precision quantizer described in Example 1 and assume it takes pâ€‹Fğ‘ğ¹pF bits to represent an unquantized vector of length pğ‘p, where Fğ¹F is typically 323232 bits.

Computation time. We consider the well-known shifted-exponential model for gradient computation time (Lee etÂ al., 2017). In particular, we assume that for any node, computing the gradients in a period with Ï„ğœ\tau iterations and using batchsize BğµB takes a deterministic shift Ï„â‹…Bâ‹…shiftâ‹…ğœğµshift\tau\cdot B\cdot\texttt{shift} plus a random exponential time with mean value Ï„â‹…Bâ‹…scaleâˆ’1â‹…ğœğµsuperscriptscale1\tau\cdot B\cdot\texttt{scale}^{-1}, where shift and scale are respectively shift and scale parameters of the shifted-exponential distribution. Total computation time of each round is then the largest local computation time among the rğ‘Ÿr contributing nodes. We also define a communication-computation ratio

CcommCcomp=pâ€‹F/BWshift+1/scalesubscriptğ¶commsubscriptğ¶compğ‘ğ¹BWshift1scale\displaystyle\frac{C_{\texttt{comm}}}{C_{\texttt{comp}}}=\frac{pF/\texttt{BW}}{\texttt{shift}+1/\texttt{scale}}

as the communication time for a length-pğ‘p-vector over the average computation time for one gradient vector. This ratio captures the relative cost of communication and computation, and since communication is a major bottleneck, we have Ccomm/Ccompâ‰«1much-greater-thansubscriptğ¶commsubscriptğ¶comp1{C_{\texttt{comm}}}/{C_{\texttt{comp}}}\gg 1. In all of our experiments, we use batchsize B=10ğµ10B=10 and finely tune the stepsizeâ€™s coefficient.

5.1 Logistic Regression on MNIST

In Figure 1, the top four plots demonstrate the training time for a regularized logistic regression problem over MNIST dataset (â€˜0â€™ and â€˜8â€™ digits) for T=100ğ‘‡100T=100 iterations. The network has n=50ğ‘›50n=50 nodes each loaded with 200200200 samples. We set Ccomm/Ccomp=100/1subscriptğ¶commsubscriptğ¶comp1001C_{\texttt{comm}}/C_{\texttt{comp}}=100/1 to capture the communication bottleneck. Among the three parameters quantization levels sğ‘ s, number of active nodes in each round rğ‘Ÿr, and period length Ï„ğœ\tau, we fix two and vary the third one. First plot demonstrates the relative training loss for different quantization levels sâˆˆ{1,5,10}ğ‘ 1510s\in\{1,5,10\} and the case with no quantization which corresponds to the FedAvg method (McMahan etÂ al., 2016). The other two parameters are fixed to (Ï„,r)=(5,25)ğœğ‘Ÿ525(\tau,r)=(5,25). Each curve shows the training time versus the achieved training loss for the aggregated model at the server for each round k=1,â‹¯,T/Ï„ğ‘˜1â‹¯ğ‘‡ğœk=1,\cdots,T/\tau. In the second plot, (s,Ï„)=(1,5)ğ‘ ğœ15(s,\tau)=(1,5) are fixed. The third plot demonstrates the effect of period length Ï„ğœ\tau in the communication-computation tradeoff. As demonstrated, after T/Ï„ğ‘‡ğœT/\tau rounds, smaller choices for Ï„ğœ\tau (e.g. Ï„=1,2ğœ12\tau=1,2) result in slower convergence while the larger ones (e.g. Ï„=50ğœ50\tau=50) run faster though providing less accurate models. Here Ï„=10ğœ10\tau=10 is the optimal choice. The last plot compares the training time of FedPAQ with two other benchmarks FedAvg and QSGD. For both FedPAQ and FedAvg, we set Ï„=2ğœ2\tau=2 while FedPAQ and QSGD use quantization with s=1ğ‘ 1s=1 level. All three methods use r=n=50ğ‘Ÿğ‘›50r=n=50 nodes in each round.

5.2 Neural Network training over CIFAR-10

We conduct another set of numerical experiments to evaluate the performance of FedPAQ on non-convex and smooth objectives. Here we train a neural network with four hidden layers consisting of n=50ğ‘›50n=50 nodes and more thatn 929292K parameters, where we use 101010K samples from CIFAR-10 dataset with 101010 labels. Since models are much larger than the previous setup, we increase the communication-computation ratio to Ccomm/Ccomp=1000/1subscriptğ¶commsubscriptğ¶comp10001C_{\texttt{comm}}/C_{\texttt{comp}}=1000/1 to better capture the communication bottleneck for large models. The bottom four plots in FigureÂ 1 demonstrate the training loss over time for T=100ğ‘‡100T=100 iterations. In the first plot, (Ï„,r)=(2,25)ğœğ‘Ÿ225(\tau,r)=(2,25) are fixed and we vary the quantization levels. The second plot shows the effect of rğ‘Ÿr while (s,Ï„)=(1,2)ğ‘ ğœ12(s,\tau)=(1,2). The communication-computation tradeoff in terms of period length Ï„ğœ\tau is demonstrated in the third plot, where picking Ï„=10ğœ10\tau=10 turns out to attain the fastest convergence. Lastly, we compare FedPAQ with other benchmarks in the forth plot. Here, we set (s,r,Ï„)=(1,20,10)ğ‘ ğ‘Ÿğœ12010(s,r,\tau)=(1,20,10) in FedPAQ, (r,Ï„)=(20,10)ğ‘Ÿğœ2010(r,\tau)=(20,10) in FedAvg and (s,r,Ï„)=(1,50,1)ğ‘ ğ‘Ÿğœ1501(s,r,\tau)=(1,50,1) for QSGD.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we addressed some of the communication and scalability challenges of federated learning and proposed FedPAQ, a communication-efficient federated learning method with provable performance guarantees. FedPAQ is based on three modules: (1) periodic averaging in which each edge node performs local iterative updates; (2) partial node participation which captures the random availability of the edge nodes; and (3) quantization in which each model is quantized before being uploaded to the server. We provided rigorous analysis for our proposed method for two general classes of strongly-convex and non-convex losses. We further provided numerical results evaluating the performance of FedPAQ, and discussing the trade-off between communication and computation.

Supplementary Materials

Here, we provide the proofs of the main two theorems of this paper in Sections 7 and 8 along with the necessary lemmas and discussions. Moreover, we provide more numerical results over more complicated datasets and model parameters in Section 9.

7 Proof of Theorem 1

We first introduce some additional notations which will be used throughput the proofs.

Additional notations. For each period k=0,1,â‹¯,Kâˆ’1ğ‘˜01â‹¯ğ¾1k=0,1,\cdots,K-1 and iteration t=0,1,â‹¯,Ï„âˆ’1ğ‘¡01â‹¯ğœ1t=0,1,\cdots,\tau-1 we denote

ğ±k+1subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1\displaystyle\mathbf{x}_{k+1} â‰”ğ±k+1râ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®kQâ€‹(ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±k),â‰”absentsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘˜ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\displaystyle\coloneqq\mathbf{x}_{k}+\frac{1}{r}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{k}}Q\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right), (22)
ğ±^k+1subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜1\displaystyle\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1} â‰”ğ±k+1nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]Qâ€‹(ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±k),â‰”absentsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\displaystyle\coloneqq\mathbf{x}_{k}+\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}Q\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right), (23)
ğ±Â¯k,tsubscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\displaystyle\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,t} â‰”1nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ğ±k,t(i).â‰”absent1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\displaystyle\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t}. (24)

We begin the proof of Theorem 1 by noting a few key observations. Based on the above notations and the assumptions we made earlier, the optimality gap of the parameter serverâ€™s model at period kğ‘˜k, i.e. ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±k+1âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1superscriptğ±2\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k+1}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}, can be decomposed as stated in the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

Consider any period k=0,â‹¯,Kâˆ’1ğ‘˜0â‹¯ğ¾1k=0,\cdots,K-1 and the sequences {ğ±k+1,ğ±^k+1,ğ±Â¯k,Ï„}subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜1subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœ\{\mathbf{x}_{k+1},\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1},\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}\} generated by the FedPAQ method in Algorithm 1. If Assumption 1 holds, then

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±k+1âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k+1}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} =ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±k+1âˆ’ğ±^k+1âˆ¥2+ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±^k+1âˆ’ğ±Â¯k,Ï„âˆ¥2+ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±Â¯k,Ï„âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2,absentğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜12ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜1subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœ2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœsuperscriptğ±2\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k+1}-\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}\right\rVert}^{2}+\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}-\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}\right\rVert}^{2}+\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}, (25)

where the expectation is with respect to all sources of randomness.

Proof.

See Section 7.1. âˆ

In the following three lemmas, we characterize each of the terms in the right-hand side (RHS) of (25).

Lemma 2.

Consider the sequence of local updates in the FedPAQ method in Algorithm 1 and let Assumptions 2, 3 and 4 hold. The optimality gap for the average model at the end of period kğ‘˜k, i.e. ğ±Â¯k,Ï„subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœ\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}, relates to that of the initial model of the kğ‘˜k-th period ğ±ksubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}_{k} as follows:

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±Â¯k,Ï„âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœsuperscriptğ±2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} â‰¤(1+nâ€‹Î·k2)â€‹(1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Î·k)Ï„â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2absent1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2superscript1ğœ‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğœğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\leq\left(1+n\eta_{k}^{2}\right)\left(1-\mu\eta_{k}\right)^{\tau}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} (26)
+Ï„â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)2â€‹L2â€‹Ïƒ2nâ€‹eâ€‹Î·k2+Ï„2â€‹Ïƒ2nâ€‹Î·k2ğœsuperscriptğœ12superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ2ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\quad+\tau(\tau-1)^{2}L^{2}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}e\eta_{k}^{2}+\tau^{2}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}\eta_{k}^{2} (27)
+Ï„2â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)â€‹L2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹eâ€‹Î·k4,superscriptğœ2ğœ1superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2ğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜4\displaystyle\quad+\tau^{2}(\tau-1)L^{2}\sigma^{2}e\eta_{k}^{4}, (28)

for the stepsize Î·kâ‰¤minâ¡{Î¼/L2,1/Lâ€‹Ï„}subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğœ‡superscriptğ¿21ğ¿ğœ\eta_{k}\leq\min\{\nicefrac{{\mu}}{{L^{2}}},\nicefrac{{1}}{{L\tau}}\}.

Proof.

See Section 7.2. âˆ

Lemma 3.

For the proposed FedPAQ method in Algorithm 1 with stepsize Î·kâ‰¤minâ¡{Î¼/L2,1/Lâ€‹Ï„}subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğœ‡superscriptğ¿21ğ¿ğœ\eta_{k}\leq\min\{\nicefrac{{\mu}}{{L^{2}}},\nicefrac{{1}}{{L\tau}}\} and under Assumptions 1, 2, 3 and 4, we have

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±^k+1âˆ’ğ±Â¯k,Ï„âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜1subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœ2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}-\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}\right\rVert}^{2} â‰¤2â€‹qnâ€‹Ï„2â€‹L2â€‹Î·k2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2+2â€‹qâ€‹Ï„2â€‹Ïƒ2nâ€‹Î·k2+2â€‹qâ€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)â€‹Ï„2â€‹L2â€‹Ïƒ2nâ€‹eâ€‹Î·k4,absent2ğ‘ğ‘›superscriptğœ2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜superscriptğ±22ğ‘superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ2ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜22ğ‘ğœ1superscriptğœ2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜4\displaystyle\leq 2\frac{q}{n}\tau^{2}L^{2}\eta_{k}^{2}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}+2q\tau^{2}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}\eta_{k}^{2}+2q(\tau-1)\tau^{2}L^{2}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}e\eta_{k}^{4}, (29)

where ğ±^k+1subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜1\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1} and ğ±Â¯k,Ï„subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœ\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau} are defined in (24).

Proof.

See Section 7.3. âˆ

Lemma 4.

For the proposed FedPAQ method in Algorithm 1 with stepsize Î·kâ‰¤minâ¡{Î¼/L2,1/Lâ€‹Ï„}subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğœ‡superscriptğ¿21ğ¿ğœ\eta_{k}\leq\min\{\nicefrac{{\mu}}{{L^{2}}},\nicefrac{{1}}{{L\tau}}\} and under Assumptions 1â€“4, we have

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±k+1âˆ’ğ±^k+1âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜12\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k+1}-\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}\right\rVert}^{2} â‰¤nâˆ’rrâ€‹(nâˆ’1)â€‹8â€‹(1+q)â€‹{Ï„2â€‹L2â€‹Î·k2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2+Ï„2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹Î·k2+(Ï„âˆ’1)â€‹Ï„2â€‹L2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹eâ€‹Î·k4},absentğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›181ğ‘superscriptğœ2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜superscriptğ±2superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2ğœ1superscriptğœ2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2ğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜4\displaystyle\leq\frac{n-r}{r(n-1)}8(1+q)\Bigg{\{}\tau^{2}L^{2}\eta_{k}^{2}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}+\tau^{2}\sigma^{2}\eta_{k}^{2}+(\tau-1)\tau^{2}L^{2}\sigma^{2}e\eta_{k}^{4}\Bigg{\}}, (30)

where rğ‘Ÿr denotes the number of nodes contributing in each period of the FedPAQ method.

Proof.

See Section 7.4. âˆ

Now that we have established the main building modules for proving Theorem 1, let us proceed with the proof by putting together the results in Lemmas 1â€“4. That is,

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±k+1âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k+1}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} â‰¤ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2â€‹((1+nâ€‹Î·k2)â€‹(1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Î·k)Ï„+2â€‹L2â€‹Ï„2â€‹Î·k2â€‹(qn+nâˆ’rrâ€‹(nâˆ’1)â€‹4â€‹(1+q)))absentğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜superscriptğ±21ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2superscript1ğœ‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğœ2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›141ğ‘\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}\left(\left(1+n\eta_{k}^{2}\right)\left(1-\mu\eta_{k}\right)^{\tau}+2L^{2}\tau^{2}\eta_{k}^{2}\left(\frac{q}{n}+\frac{n-r}{r(n-1)}4(1+q)\right)\right) (31)
+(1+2â€‹q+8â€‹(1+q)â€‹nâ€‹(nâˆ’r)râ€‹(nâˆ’1))â€‹Ïƒ2nâ€‹Ï„2â€‹Î·k212ğ‘81ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›1superscriptğœ2ğ‘›superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\quad+\left(1+2q+8(1+q)\frac{n(n-r)}{r(n-1)}\right)\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}\tau^{2}\eta_{k}^{2} (32)
+L2â€‹Ïƒ2nâ€‹eâ€‹Ï„â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)2â€‹Î·k2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘’ğœsuperscriptğœ12superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\quad+L^{2}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}e\tau(\tau-1)^{2}\eta_{k}^{2} (33)
+(n+2â€‹q+8â€‹(1+q)â€‹nâ€‹(nâˆ’r)râ€‹(nâˆ’1))â€‹L2â€‹Ïƒ2nâ€‹eâ€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)â€‹Ï„2â€‹Î·k4ğ‘›2ğ‘81ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›1superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘’ğœ1superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜4\displaystyle\quad+\left(n+2q+8(1+q)\frac{n(n-r)}{r(n-1)}\right)L^{2}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}e(\tau-1)\tau^{2}\eta_{k}^{4} (34)

Let us set the following notations:

Î´ksubscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜\displaystyle\delta_{k} â‰”ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2,â‰”absentğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\coloneqq\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}, (35)
C0subscriptğ¶0\displaystyle C_{0} â‰”(1+nâ€‹Î·k2)â€‹(1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Î·k)Ï„+2â€‹L2â€‹Ï„2â€‹Î·k2â€‹(qn+nâˆ’rrâ€‹(nâˆ’1)â€‹4â€‹(1+q)),â‰”absent1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2superscript1ğœ‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğœ2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›141ğ‘\displaystyle\coloneqq\left(1+n\eta_{k}^{2}\right)\left(1-\mu\eta_{k}\right)^{\tau}+2L^{2}\tau^{2}\eta_{k}^{2}\left(\frac{q}{n}+\frac{n-r}{r(n-1)}4(1+q)\right), (36)
C1subscriptğ¶1\displaystyle C_{1} â‰”16Î¼2â€‹(1+2â€‹q+8â€‹(1+q)â€‹nâ€‹(nâˆ’r)râ€‹(nâˆ’1))â€‹Ïƒ2n,â‰”absent16superscriptğœ‡212ğ‘81ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›1superscriptğœ2ğ‘›\displaystyle\coloneqq\frac{16}{\mu^{2}}\left(1+2q+8(1+q)\frac{n(n-r)}{r(n-1)}\right)\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}, (37)
C2subscriptğ¶2\displaystyle C_{2} â‰”16Î¼2â€‹L2â€‹Ïƒ2nâ€‹e,â‰”absent16superscriptğœ‡2superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘’\displaystyle\coloneqq\frac{16}{\mu^{2}}L^{2}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}e, (38)
C3subscriptğ¶3\displaystyle C_{3} â‰”256Î¼4â€‹(n+2â€‹q+8â€‹(1+q)â€‹nâ€‹(nâˆ’r)râ€‹(nâˆ’1))â€‹L2â€‹Ïƒ2nâ€‹e.â‰”absent256superscriptğœ‡4ğ‘›2ğ‘81ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘›1superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘’\displaystyle\coloneqq\frac{256}{\mu^{4}}\left(n+2q+8(1+q)\frac{n(n-r)}{r(n-1)}\right)L^{2}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}e. (39)

Consider C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0}, the coefficient of ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜superscriptğ±2\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} in (34). One can show that if the condition in (11) in Theorem 1 is satisfied, then we have C0â‰¤1âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Ï„â€‹Î·ksubscriptğ¶0112ğœ‡ğœsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜C_{0}\leq 1-\frac{1}{2}\mu\tau\eta_{k} (See Section 7.6). Therefore, for each period kâ‰¥k0ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘˜0k\geq k_{0} we have

Î´k+1â‰¤(1âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Ï„â€‹Î·k)â€‹Î´k+Î¼216â€‹C1â€‹Ï„2â€‹Î·k2+Î¼216â€‹C2â€‹Ï„â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)2â€‹Î·k2+Î¼4256â€‹C3â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)â€‹Ï„2â€‹Î·k4.subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜1112ğœ‡ğœsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜superscriptğœ‡216subscriptğ¶1superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2superscriptğœ‡216subscriptğ¶2ğœsuperscriptğœ12superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2superscriptğœ‡4256subscriptğ¶3ğœ1superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜4\displaystyle\delta_{k+1}\leq\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\mu\tau\eta_{k}\right)\delta_{k}+\frac{\mu^{2}}{16}C_{1}\tau^{2}\eta_{k}^{2}+\frac{\mu^{2}}{16}C_{2}\tau(\tau-1)^{2}\eta_{k}^{2}+\frac{\mu^{4}}{256}C_{3}(\tau-1)\tau^{2}\eta_{k}^{4}. (40)

Now, we substitute the stepsize Î·k=4â€‹Î¼âˆ’1/kâ€‹Ï„+1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜4superscriptğœ‡1ğ‘˜ğœ1\eta_{k}=\nicefrac{{4\mu^{-1}}}{{k\tau+1}} in (40) which yields

Î´k+1â‰¤(1âˆ’2k+1/Ï„)â€‹Î´k+C1â€‹1(k+1/Ï„)2+C2â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)2Ï„â€‹1(k+1/Ï„)2+C3â€‹Ï„âˆ’1Ï„2â€‹1(k+1/Ï„)4.subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜112ğ‘˜1ğœsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜subscriptğ¶11superscriptğ‘˜1ğœ2subscriptğ¶2superscriptğœ12ğœ1superscriptğ‘˜1ğœ2subscriptğ¶3ğœ1superscriptğœ21superscriptğ‘˜1ğœ4\displaystyle\delta_{k+1}\leq\left(1-\frac{2}{k+1/\tau}\right)\delta_{k}+C_{1}\frac{1}{(k+1/\tau)^{2}}+C_{2}\frac{(\tau-1)^{2}}{\tau}\frac{1}{(k+1/\tau)^{2}}+C_{3}\frac{\tau-1}{\tau^{2}}\frac{1}{(k+1/\tau)^{4}}. (41)

In Lemma 5, we show the convergence analysis of such sequence. In particular, we take k1=1/Ï„subscriptğ‘˜11ğœk_{1}=1/\tau, a=C1+C2â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)2/Ï„ğ‘subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2superscriptğœ12ğœa=C_{1}+C_{2}{(\tau-1)^{2}}/{\tau} and b=C3â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)/Ï„2ğ‘subscriptğ¶3ğœ1superscriptğœ2b=C_{3}({\tau-1})/{\tau^{2}} in Lemma 5 and conclude for any kâ‰¥k0ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘˜0k\geq k_{0} that

Î´kâ‰¤(k0+1/Ï„)2(k+1/Ï„)2â€‹Î´k0+C1â€‹1k+1/Ï„+C2â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)2Ï„â€‹1k+1/Ï„+C3â€‹Ï„âˆ’1Ï„2â€‹1(k+1/Ï„)2.subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜01ğœ2superscriptğ‘˜1ğœ2subscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘˜0subscriptğ¶11ğ‘˜1ğœsubscriptğ¶2superscriptğœ12ğœ1ğ‘˜1ğœsubscriptğ¶3ğœ1superscriptğœ21superscriptğ‘˜1ğœ2\displaystyle\delta_{k}\leq\frac{(k_{0}+1/\tau)^{2}}{(k+1/\tau)^{2}}\delta_{k_{0}}+C_{1}\frac{1}{k+1/\tau}+C_{2}\frac{(\tau-1)^{2}}{\tau}\frac{1}{k+1/\tau}+C_{3}\frac{\tau-1}{\tau^{2}}\frac{1}{(k+1/\tau)^{2}}. (42)

Finally, rearranging the terms in (42) yields the desired result in Theorem 1, that is

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} â‰¤(k0â€‹Ï„+1)2(kâ€‹Ï„+1)2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±k0âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2+C1â€‹Ï„kâ€‹Ï„+1+C2â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)2kâ€‹Ï„+1+C3â€‹Ï„âˆ’1(kâ€‹Ï„+1)2.absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğœ12superscriptğ‘˜ğœ12ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±subscriptğ‘˜0superscriptğ±2subscriptğ¶1ğœğ‘˜ğœ1subscriptğ¶2superscriptğœ12ğ‘˜ğœ1subscriptğ¶3ğœ1superscriptğ‘˜ğœ12\displaystyle\leq\frac{(k_{0}\tau+1)^{2}}{(k\tau+1)^{2}}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k_{0}}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}+C_{1}\frac{\tau}{k\tau+1}+C_{2}\frac{(\tau-1)^{2}}{k\tau+1}+C_{3}\frac{\tau-1}{(k\tau+1)^{2}}. (43)

7.1 Proof of Lemma 1

Let â„±k,tsubscriptâ„±ğ‘˜ğ‘¡{\mathcal{F}}_{k,t} denote the history of all sources of randomness by the tğ‘¡t-th iteration in period kğ‘˜k. The following expectation arguments are conditional on the history â„±k,Ï„subscriptâ„±ğ‘˜ğœ{\mathcal{F}}_{k,\tau} which we remove in our notations for simplicity. Since the random subset of nodes ğ’®ksubscriptğ’®ğ‘˜{\mathcal{S}}_{k} is uniformly picked from the set of all the nodes [n]delimited-[]ğ‘›[n], we can write

ğ”¼ğ’®kâ€‹ğ±k+1subscriptğ”¼subscriptğ’®ğ‘˜subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{{\mathcal{S}}_{k}}\mathbf{x}_{k+1} =ğ±k+ğ”¼ğ’®kâ€‹1râ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®kQâ€‹(ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±k)absentsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğ”¼subscriptğ’®ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘˜ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\displaystyle=\mathbf{x}_{k}+\mathbb{E}_{{\mathcal{S}}_{k}}\frac{1}{r}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{k}}Q\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right) (44)
=ğ±k+âˆ‘ğ’®âŠ†[n]|ğ’®|=rPrâ€‹[ğ’®k=ğ’®]â€‹1râ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®kQâ€‹(ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±k)absentsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğ’®delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ’®ğ‘ŸPrdelimited-[]subscriptğ’®ğ‘˜ğ’®1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ’®ğ‘˜ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\displaystyle=\mathbf{x}_{k}+\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}{\mathcal{S}}\subseteq[n]\\ |{\mathcal{S}}|=r\end{subarray}}\text{Pr}\left[{\mathcal{S}}_{k}={\mathcal{S}}\right]\frac{1}{r}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}_{k}}Q\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right) (45)
=ğ±k+1(nr)â€‹1râ€‹(nâˆ’1râˆ’1)â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]Qâ€‹(ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±k)absentsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜1binomialğ‘›ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘Ÿbinomialğ‘›1ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\displaystyle=\mathbf{x}_{k}+\frac{1}{{n\choose r}}\frac{1}{r}{n-1\choose r-1}\sum_{i\in[n]}Q\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right) (46)
=ğ±k+1nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]Qâ€‹(ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±k)absentsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\displaystyle=\mathbf{x}_{k}+\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}Q\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right) (47)
=ğ±^k+1.absentsubscript^ğ±ğ‘˜1\displaystyle=\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}. (48)

Moreover, the quantizer Qâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘„â‹…Q(\cdot) is unbiased according to Assumption 1, which yields

ğ”¼Qâ€‹ğ±^k+1subscriptğ”¼ğ‘„subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜1\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{Q}\,\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1} =ğ±k+1nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ğ”¼Qâ€‹Qâ€‹(ğ±k,Ï„(i)âˆ’ğ±k)absentsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ”¼ğ‘„ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\displaystyle=\mathbf{x}_{k}+\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbb{E}_{Q}\,Q\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}_{k}\right) (49)
=1nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ğ±k,Ï„(i)absent1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœ\displaystyle=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau} (50)
=ğ±Â¯k,Ï„.absentsubscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœ\displaystyle=\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}. (51)

Finally, since the two randomnesses induced by the quantization and random sampling are independent, together with (48) and (51) we can conclude that:

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±k+1âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k+1}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} =ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±k+1âˆ’ğ±^k+1+ğ±^k+1âˆ’ğ±Â¯k,Ï„+ğ±Â¯k,Ï„âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2absentğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜1subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜1subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœsuperscriptğ±2\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k+1}-\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}+\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}-\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}+\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} (52)
=ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±k+1âˆ’ğ±^k+1âˆ¥2+ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±^k+1âˆ’ğ±Â¯k,Ï„âˆ¥2+ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±Â¯k,Ï„âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2.absentğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜1subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜12ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscript^ğ±ğ‘˜1subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœ2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœsuperscriptğ±2\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k+1}-\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}\right\rVert}^{2}+\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\widehat{\mathbf{x}}_{k+1}-\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}\right\rVert}^{2}+\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}. (53)

7.2 Proof of Lemma 2

According to update rule in Algorithm 1, local model at node iğ‘–i for each iteration t=0,â‹¯,Ï„âˆ’1ğ‘¡0â‹¯ğœ1t=0,\cdots,\tau-1 of period k=0,â‹¯,Kâˆ’1ğ‘˜0â‹¯ğ¾1k=0,\cdots,K-1 can be written as follows:

ğ±k,t+1(i)subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t+1} =ğ±k,t(i)âˆ’Î·kâ€‹âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±k,t(i)),absentsubscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\displaystyle=\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t}-\eta_{k}\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t}\right), (54)

where all the nodes start the period with the initial model ğ±k,0(i)=ğ±ksubscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜0subscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,0}=\mathbf{x}_{k}. In parallel, let us define another sequence of updates as follows:

Î²k,t+1subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\beta_{k,t+1} =Î²k,tâˆ’Î·kâ€‹âˆ‡fâ€‹(Î²k,t),absentsubscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\displaystyle=\beta_{k,t}-\eta_{k}\nabla f\left(\beta_{k,t}\right), (55)

also starting with Î²k,0=ğ±ksubscriptğ›½ğ‘˜0subscriptğ±ğ‘˜\beta_{k,0}=\mathbf{x}_{k}. The auxiliary sequence {Î²k,t}subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\{\beta_{k,t}\} represents Gradient Descent updates over the global loss function fğ‘“f while ğ±k,t(i)subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t} captures the sequence of SGD updates on each local node. However, both sequences are initialized with ğ±ksubscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}_{k} at the beginning of each period kğ‘˜k. To evaluate the deviation âˆ¥ğ±Â¯k,Ï„âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœsuperscriptğ±2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}, we link the two sequences. In particular, let us define the following notations for each k=0,â‹¯,Kâˆ’1ğ‘˜0â‹¯ğ¾1k=0,\cdots,K-1 and t=0,â‹¯,Ï„âˆ’1ğ‘¡0â‹¯ğœ1t=0,\cdots,\tau-1:

ğk,tsubscriptğğ‘˜ğ‘¡\displaystyle{\mathbf{e}}_{k,t} =1nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±k,t(i))âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(Î²k,t).absent1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\displaystyle=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t}\right)-\nabla f\left(\beta_{k,t}\right). (56)

One can easily observe that ğ”¼â€‹ğk,0=0ğ”¼subscriptğğ‘˜00\mathbb{E}{\mathbf{e}}_{k,0}=0 as ğ±k,0(i)=Î²k,0=ğ±ksubscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜0subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜0subscriptğ±ğ‘˜\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,0}=\beta_{k,0}=\mathbf{x}_{k} and âˆ‡~â€‹fi~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i} is unbiased for âˆ‡fâˆ‡ğ‘“\nabla f. However, ğ”¼â€‹ğk,tâ‰ 0ğ”¼subscriptğğ‘˜ğ‘¡0\mathbb{E}{\mathbf{e}}_{k,t}\neq 0 for tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1. In other words, 1nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±k,t(i))1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,t}) is not unbiased for âˆ‡fâ€‹(Î²k,t)âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\nabla f(\beta_{k,t}). We also define ğk=ğk,0+â‹¯+ğk,Ï„âˆ’1subscriptğğ‘˜subscriptğğ‘˜0â‹¯subscriptğğ‘˜ğœ1{\mathbf{e}}_{k}={\mathbf{e}}_{k,0}+\cdots+{\mathbf{e}}_{k,\tau-1} and ğ k=âˆ‡fâ€‹(Î²k,0)+â‹¯+âˆ‡fâ€‹(Î²k,Ï„âˆ’1)subscriptğ ğ‘˜âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜0â‹¯âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğœ1{\mathbf{g}}_{k}=\nabla f(\beta_{k,0})+\cdots+\nabla f(\beta_{k,\tau-1}). Now, the average model obtained at the end of period kğ‘˜k can be written as

ğ±Â¯k,Ï„subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœ\displaystyle\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau} =1nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ğ±k,Ï„(i)absent1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœ\displaystyle=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau} (57)
=ğ±kâˆ’Î·kâ€‹(1nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±k,0(i))+â‹¯+1nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‡~â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±k,Ï„âˆ’1(i)))absentsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜0â‹¯1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›~âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœ1\displaystyle=\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta_{k}\left(\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,0}\right)+\cdots+\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\widetilde{\nabla}f_{i}\left(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{k,\tau-1}\right)\right) (58)
=ğ±kâˆ’Î·kâ€‹(ğ k+ğk).absentsubscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ ğ‘˜subscriptğğ‘˜\displaystyle=\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta_{k}\left({\mathbf{g}}_{k}+{\mathbf{e}}_{k}\right). (59)

Therefore, the optimality gap for the averaged model can be written as

ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±Â¯k,Ï„âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜ğœsuperscriptğ±2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\overline{\mathbf{x}}_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} =ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’Î·kâ€‹ğ kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2âˆ’2â€‹Î·kâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹âŸ¨ğ±kâˆ’Î·kâ€‹ğ kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—,ğkâŸ©+Î·k2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğkâˆ¥2absentğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ ğ‘˜superscriptğ±22subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğ”¼subscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ ğ‘˜superscriptğ±subscriptğğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğğ‘˜2\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta_{k}{\mathbf{g}}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}-2\eta_{k}\mathbb{E}\left\langle\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta_{k}{\mathbf{g}}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*},{\mathbf{e}}_{k}\right\rangle+\eta_{k}^{2}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert{\mathbf{e}}_{k}\right\rVert}^{2} (60)
â‰¤ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’Î·kâ€‹ğ kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2absentğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ ğ‘˜superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta_{k}{\mathbf{g}}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} (61)
+nâ€‹Î·k2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’Î·kâ€‹ğ kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2+1nâ€‹âˆ¥ğ”¼â€‹ğkâˆ¥2ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ ğ‘˜superscriptğ±21ğ‘›superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ”¼subscriptğğ‘˜2\displaystyle\quad+n\eta_{k}^{2}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta_{k}{\mathbf{g}}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}+\frac{1}{n}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbb{E}{\mathbf{e}}_{k}\right\rVert}^{2} (62)
+Î·k2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğkâˆ¥2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğğ‘˜2\displaystyle\quad+\eta_{k}^{2}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert{\mathbf{e}}_{k}\right\rVert}^{2} (63)
=(1+nâ€‹Î·k2)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’Î·kâ€‹ğ kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2+1nâ€‹âˆ¥ğ”¼â€‹ğkâˆ¥2+Î·k2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹âˆ¥ğkâˆ¥2,absent1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ ğ‘˜superscriptğ±21ğ‘›superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ”¼subscriptğğ‘˜2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2ğ”¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğğ‘˜2\displaystyle=\left(1+n\eta_{k}^{2}\right)\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta_{k}{\mathbf{g}}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}+\frac{1}{n}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbb{E}{\mathbf{e}}_{k}\right\rVert}^{2}+\eta_{k}^{2}\mathbb{E}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert{\mathbf{e}}_{k}\right\rVert}^{2}, (64)

where we used the inequality âˆ’2â€‹âŸ¨ğš,ğ›âŸ©â‰¤Î±â€‹âˆ¥ğšâˆ¥2+Î±âˆ’1â€‹âˆ¥ğ›âˆ¥22ğšğ›ğ›¼superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğš2superscriptğ›¼1superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ›2-2\langle{\mathbf{a}},{\mathbf{b}}\rangle\leq\alpha\mathinner{\!\left\lVert{\mathbf{a}}\right\rVert}^{2}+\alpha^{-1}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert{\mathbf{b}}\right\rVert}^{2} for any two vectors ğš,ğ›ğšğ›{\mathbf{a}},{\mathbf{b}} and scalar Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0. In the following, we bound each of the three terms in the RHS of (64). First, consider the term âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’Î·kâ€‹ğ kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ ğ‘˜superscriptğ±2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta_{k}{\mathbf{g}}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} and recall the auxiliary sequence {Î²k,t}subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\{\beta_{k,t}\} defined in (68). For every tğ‘¡t and kğ‘˜k we have

âˆ¥Î²k,t+1âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡1superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\beta_{k,t+1}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} =âˆ¥Î²k,tâˆ’Î·kâ€‹âˆ‡fâ€‹(Î²k,t)âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2absentsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptğ±2\displaystyle=\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\beta_{k,t}-\eta_{k}\nabla f(\beta_{k,t})-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} (65)
=âˆ¥Î²k,tâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2âˆ’2â€‹Î·kâ€‹âŸ¨Î²k,tâˆ’ğ±âˆ—,âˆ‡fâ€‹(Î²k,t)âŸ©+Î·k2â€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(Î²k,t)âˆ¥2absentsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptğ±22subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptğ±âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡2\displaystyle=\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\beta_{k,t}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}-2\eta_{k}\left\langle\beta_{k,t}-\mathbf{x}^{*},\nabla f(\beta_{k,t})\right\rangle+\eta_{k}^{2}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\nabla f(\beta_{k,t})\right\rVert}^{2} (66)
â‰¤(1âˆ’2â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·k+L2â€‹Î·k2)â€‹âˆ¥Î²k,tâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2absent12ğœ‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\leq\left(1-2\mu\eta_{k}+L^{2}\eta_{k}^{2}\right)\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\beta_{k,t}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} (67)
â‰¤(1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Î·k)â€‹âˆ¥Î²k,tâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2.absent1ğœ‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\leq(1-\mu\eta_{k})\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\beta_{k,t}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}. (68)

In the above derivations, we used the facts that fğ‘“f is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex and its gradient is Lğ¿L-Lipschitz (Assumptions 2 and 4). The stepsize is also picked such that Î·kâ‰¤Î¼/L2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğœ‡superscriptğ¿2\eta_{k}\leq\nicefrac{{\mu}}{{L^{2}}}. Now, conditioned on the history â„±k,0subscriptâ„±ğ‘˜0{\mathcal{F}}_{k,0} and using (68) we have

âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’Î·kâ€‹ğ kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜subscriptğ ğ‘˜superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\eta_{k}{\mathbf{g}}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} =âˆ¥Î²k,Ï„âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2absentsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜ğœsuperscriptğ±2\displaystyle=\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\beta_{k,\tau}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} (69)
â‰¤(1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Î·k)Ï„â€‹âˆ¥Î²k,0âˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2absentsuperscript1ğœ‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğœsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜0superscriptğ±2\displaystyle\leq\left(1-\mu\eta_{k}\right)^{\tau}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\beta_{k,0}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2} (70)
=(1âˆ’Î¼â€‹Î·k)Ï„â€‹âˆ¥ğ±kâˆ’ğ±âˆ—âˆ¥2.absentsuperscript1ğœ‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğœsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘˜superscriptğ±2\displaystyle=\left(1-\mu\eta_{k}\right)^{\tau}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{k}-\mathbf{x}^{*}\right\rVert}^{2}. (71)

Secondly, consider the term âˆ¥ğ”¼â€‹ğkâˆ¥2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ”¼subscriptğğ‘˜2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathbb{E}{\mathbf{e}}_{k}\right\rVert}^{2} in (64).
